RiskFactors.explanation_investors: This bridge has 2 distinct vulnerability classes creating compounding risk. When signature verification weaknesses and cross-chain message validation gaps are both present, the attack surface compounds — a breach in one layer can be leveraged through the other. The 1.3x multiplier reflects the increased likelihood of exploitation when multiple vectors exist simultaneously.
RiskFactors.explanation_developers: CRITICAL: 2 distinct vulnerability vectors compound risk. Vectors: signature verification weaknesses and cross-chain message validation gaps. Both must be addressed simultaneously — partial remediation leaves the remaining vector exposed to exploitation through the unpatched path.

RiskFactors.full_evidence: Signature verification bypass — critical bridge vulnerability
RiskFactors.explanation_investors: The bridge's signature verification — the process that confirms withdrawals are legitimate — can be bypassed. Bridges require multiple signers to approve transactions (like a safe needing multiple keys). When replay protection or threshold checks are missing, an attacker can reuse old approvals or forge new ones to drain funds. The Ronin Bridge lost $625M through exactly this type of signature bypass. Do not hold significant value on bridges where this weakness exists.
RiskFactors.explanation_developers: Hash payloads with domain-separated replay IDs, enforce minimum signature thresholds, and reject already-processed message hashes before executing withdrawals.

cir_explanation.title: Bridge Signature Verification Bypass
cir_explanation.summary: Signature aggregation logic skips nonce or replay checks, letting forged payloads mint or withdraw across chains. Ensure bridge handlers verify unique nonces and enforce signature thresholds before calling mint or withdraw functions.

RiskFactors.explanation_investors: The bridge's cross-chain message handling has insufficient validation, meaning messages could be manipulated or forged. exploit_meta.name: Ronin Bridge
exploit_meta.description: State-sponsored attackers compromised 5 of 9 validator keys via social engineering, then signed fraudulent withdrawals to drain the bridge

sections.title: The Largest Smart Contract Exploit in History
sections.text: March 23, 2022: The Ronin Bridge — the sole gateway between the Ethereum mainnet and the Ronin sidechain powering Axie Infinity — is drained of $625M in ETH and USDC. The attack isn't a smart contract bug. It's a key compromise: North Korea's Lazarus Group obtains control of 5 out of 9 validator private keys, giving them signing authority over the bridge. They simply approve their own withdrawals.

sections.title: The LinkedIn Job Offer
sections.text: The attack vector is social engineering at nation-state scale. Lazarus Group targets Sky Mavis engineers with fake LinkedIn job offers. One senior engineer downloads a malicious PDF disguised as a compensation package. The payload gives the attackers access to Sky Mavis's internal infrastructure and four of the nine validator keys. A fifth key is available through the Axie DAO — a temporary gas-free transaction arrangement that was never revoked. Five of nine. Threshold reached.

sections.title: Six Days of Silence
sections.text: The most chilling detail: nobody notices for six days. The Ronin Bridge processes withdrawals normally during this period. It takes a user trying to withdraw 5,000 ETH and failing — because the bridge is empty — to trigger the discovery. Six days of a $625M breach going undetected exposes the monitoring gap that plagues bridge infrastructure across the industry.

sections.title: The Validator Threshold Problem
sections.text: Ronin's 5-of-9 multisig was a known risk concentration. Nine validators is a small set. A 56% threshold means compromising just five keys — held by a single company and its close partners — grants total control. Our engine flags exactly this pattern: small validator sets, low thresholds, and bridge signature verification that accepts whatever the validators approve. The $625M loss is the cost of trusting a small group with an irreversible signing authority.

breakdown.vulnerability: Validator key compromise — 5 of 9 keys seized via social engineering
breakdown.steps: 1) Lazarus Group identifies Sky Mavis engineers as targets and sends fake LinkedIn job offers with malicious PDF attachments. 2) A senior engineer opens the payload, compromising internal infrastructure and exposing 4 validator private keys controlled by Sky Mavis. 3) A 5th key is accessible through the Axie DAO via a temporary gas-free RPC arrangement that was never revoked. 4) With 5 of 9 keys (above the signing threshold), the attackers forge withdrawal transactions and sign them with the compromised validators. 5) Two transactions drain 173,600 ETH and 25.5M USDC ($625M total) from the Ronin Bridge contract. 6) The breach goes undetected for 6 days until a user reports a failed withdrawal.
